content: we have some noisy neighbors who are constantly shouting and fighting. my husband already talked to this guys commander about it but i am not sure if his commander even mentioned it to him. i am not sure what the next step should be. i dont want to call security forces because i dont want to get our neighbor or his wife in trouble. i heard she scould lose her command sponsorhip if she is involved in something like that. i just want them to be quiet!! is going to housing the next step and if i do, what happens then?

content: quote: Originally posted by shoecat: we have some noisy neighbors who are constantly shouting and fighting. my husband already talked to this guys commander about it but i am not sure if his commander even mentioned it to him. i am not sure what the next step should be. i dont want to call security forces because i dont want to get our neighbor or his wife in trouble. i heard she scould lose her command sponsorhip if she is involved in something like that. i just want them to be quiet!! is going to housing the next step and if i do, what happens then? Let them know that is the next step. You don't owe them anything. If they are discourteous in answer to you being a courteous neighbor, warm 'em, then report 'em... That's what laws and regulations are for - just don't get in the middle... Wandering and Wondering

title: noisy neighbors

content: We had a neighbor in civilian suburb near a Navy Base who was a MARINE. He and his wife argued a lot and were very vocal. They were great neighbors and "Hete" was a great guy and his wife was a nice as pie. My Dad always said it was their business what was going on. They were never physical but they did fight verbally. This was in the early sixties and people treated their neighbors a bit differently than they do now. If the argument is spilling into your home through the walls that's a different story and could cause your children some anxiety. Maybe if you talked to the wife, like "G" says if they can be courteous about it then work it out. Nobody needs trouble either and you might want to avoid that. Quantum materiae materietur marmota monax si marmota monax materiam possit materiari?
reply: We had a neighbor in civilian suburb near a Navy Base who was a MARINE. He and his wife argued a lot and were very vocal. They were great neighbors and "Hete" was a great guy and his wife was a nice as pie. My Dad always said it was their business what was going on. They were never physical but they did fight verbally. This was in the early sixties and people treated their neighbors a bit differently than they do now. If the argument is spilling into your home through the walls that's a different story and could cause your children some anxiety. Maybe if you talked to the wife, like "G" says if they can be courteous about it then work it out. Nobody needs trouble either and you might want to avoid that. content: Before we moved there was alot of that going on in the housing complex I lived at. I wouldn't call the cops or complain unless things got violent. You could always take a broomstick and tap on the walls. Sometimes ppl just don't know they are being loud. If that doesn't work, talk to them, if that doesn't work, then take it up with the housing office, in that order. "It is the weak who are cruel. Gentleness can only be expected from the strong" -- Leo Roskin
reply: Before we moved there was alot of that going on in the housing complex I lived at. I wouldn't call the cops or complain unless things got violent. content: quote: Originally posted by boughtwaprice: BTW-why would she loose her CS? That doesn't make sense. Bought... On some bases, families can only get 'base housing' if their spouse(s) gets this 'bennie'... Had a few cases like that in Germany, and stateside. Knew a few families got 86'd from BH in the Ansbach Military Community when their kids 'were uncontrollable', or the spouse caused a problem...the military member got 'moved to barracks', and the family was packed and shipped to CONUS in as short as 96 hours. Even happened to a few families who lived 'on the economy'...

content: Try to be nice, ask them how their day has been, just be cool. Get them into a nice conversation, you want them to relax, maybe have them over for coffee. Slowly and calmly mention the noise, see what happens. If that dosen't work then ask the base Chaplin for help. He or She could talk to them, if all else fails, take the next step. You have a right to peace and quiet in your home! Keep smiling, everyone will wonder what you've been up to!

content: quote: Originally posted by Hoffy1951: quote: Originally posted by boughtwaprice: BTW-why would she loose her CS? That doesn't make sense. Bought... On some bases, families can only get 'base housing' if their spouse(s) gets this 'bennie'... Had a few cases like that in Germany, and stateside. Knew a few families got 86'd from BH in the Ansbach Military Community when their kids 'were uncontrollable', or the spouse caused a problem...the military member got 'moved to barracks', and the family was packed and shipped to CONUS in as short as 96 hours. Even happened to a few families who lived 'on the economy'... Gotcha. There is a 3 strike rule. They won't kick you off post/base after one complaint. The lady across from me called the cops on her neigbors twice for Domestic violence. Cops never hauled anyone in as they played the ''officer, we don't know what you're talking about''. They are still there last i heard. The only time you get into trouble,or kicked out is if you are living against the regs. I got some neighbors kicked out b/c the soldier had ppl living there that had no right, and they were a menace to the neighborhood. I finally called housing, and they were gone in 2 weeks! "It is the weak who are cruel. Gentleness can only be expected from the strong" -- Leo Roskin

content: how does the 3 strike rule work? does the complaint my husband made to the neighbors chain of command count or does it have to be an "official" complaint? like i said, i dont want any trouble for anyone, it just gets annoying hearing angry voices all the time!

Someone in the Building should be appointed as the POC for any disputes or information. Going to the individuals Commander seems a little extreme without exhaustin other means. Number one, The platoon SGT comes first then his 1SGT. His Commander is going to pass the buck to the 1SGT anyway. 1968-1989 lived in many of Quarters. content: My fuse gets real short with situations like this. I will always ask once (unless something physical is going on). I will normally ask twice. After that, it's the police's problem. I'm done being nice. Interruptions to my sleep will NOT be taken lightly! There are only three reasons for waking me up. 1.) You are nekked. 2.) You are inquiring about the location of the fire extinguisher. 3.) Both! DON'T WAKE ME UP!
reply: My fuse gets real short with situations like this. I will always ask once (unless something physical is going on). I will normally ask twice. After that, it's the police's problem. title: noisy neighbors

content: In life one always has choices. Do do something or to do nothing. Like some members have suggested above. Knock on the door and speak to the head of the house hold there. Tell him/her how you feel and then let it ride for a day or two. If they continue to fight start your climb up the chain of command. Normally the IG is the last stop. Who knows you might be doing them a favor in the end.
